posts.name: Rishabh
posts.cooked:
Welcome to the Steel Talons 2025 Build Blog!

T his is our first year doing a build blog so it will probably be updated weekly or biweekly. This year we will be competing at the FiT San Antonio and FiT Space City event. We hope to continue our 2 year streak of reaching Worlds and build a highly competitive robot. The current goals list for the robot is:

Deep Cage

All Levels Coral

Score into net without needing processor

100% Coral Placement Accuracy

Due to facility constraints we were unable to start prototyping until Monday, and over the past couple of days we have been working on out intake subsystems, specifically a coral ground intake.

Coral Ground Intake Testing:

posts.name: Rishabh
posts.cooked:
Hey y’all! Today we ended up refining our prototype for the Over-The-Bumper intake and decided that due to use needing a bottom roller, we would use a slapdown as opposed to 4 bar. Here’s some footage of the testing:

We also started working on a way to straighten out the coral to feed into the end effector. We found that it would be easier to do this rather than make a wrist to reorient the coral on the end effector.

Feel free to ask any questions!

posts.name: Rishabh
posts.cooked:
Hey y’all just another update on our bot!

We’ve hit a giant roadblock in trying to both get the coral from the floor and straighten it into our end effector. The main problem that we are facing is that with the above design the game piece is too fast when it enters so it doesn’t straighten out but when we slow down the intake rollers the CORAL can’t make it over the bumpers. The initial concept for the reorienter/straightener was to use either passive Lexan in the shape of a funnel or two powered wheels similar to 254’s 2022 robot intake (shown below).

image 527×512 60.8 KB

image 527×512 60.8 KB

image 527×512 60.8 KB

So far we have made good progress with climb. The plan is to use two claws to grip onto the deep cage and then pivot the frame up similar to 148’s 2010 robot:

image 750×528 65.2 KB

image 750×528 65.2 KB

image 750×528 65.2 KB

We have a 9 hour long build session tomorrow so hopefully we can figure something out tomorrow. The only thing left to iron out is the ground intake, so we should still be on track to have a completely CADded out design by Thursday.

posts.name: Rishabh
posts.cooked:
After much deliberation we decided that instead of trying to make a separate coral floor intake we would do something like RoboChargers in 2023 with an arm on a wrist:

image 603×737 97.2 KB

image 603×737 97.2 KB

image 603×737 97.2 KB

We tested out the coral part of the intake and it proved to have some pretty good results

Floor Intake Test:

Coral Station Test:

Were expecting to finish CAD by Wednesday this week, so expect a model soon!

posts.name: Rishabh
posts.cooked:
We finally decided on an overall archetype and CAD is almost finished. Currently we have our drivetrain bars milled (28 x 28) and are currently cutting parts for our elevator. CAD release is expected in the next week.

Due to winter storm Enzo hitting Houston our district shut down our robotics facility, along with schools, till Thursday. We hope everyone is keeping warm and staying safe! (fingers crossed that we don’t loose power… again)

Sneak Peek: Gearbox Focus 1624×840 157 KB

Gearbox Focus 1624×840 157 KB

Gearbox Focus 1624×840 157 KB

posts.name: Rishabh
posts.cooked:
CAD had been completed and we’ve shifted into the manufacturing stage of our season. We received our MK4n swerve modules from SDS on Friday and were able to finish building them by Saturday afternoon. Our drivetrain bars have finished being milled and we cut out our bellypan on Saturday as well. By the end of the day we able to have our drivebase assembled.

image 1280×2270 432 KB

image 1280×2270 432 KB

image 1280×2270 432 KB

We continued testing our multiffector prototype and found that it compressed the Algae too much, but coral intaking was fine.

We had our rookies build the kitbot since we started the season and they finished up on Friday!

image 1280×2276 328 KB

image 1280×2276 328 KB

image 1280×2276 328 KB

posts.name: Rishabh
posts.cooked:
Oh boy has it been a while. Were currently fully in our manufacturing stage of our robot. However were still waiting on a key part to arrive, the SDS bearing blocks.

Last year, we tried to paint parts of our robot black with spray paint and paint marker which, while looking good for a while, wore our really fast. So this year after talking with @LadyCans-FRC2881 last year about their robot coloring process we decided to use vinyl and make our robot black and silver, to match our teams main colors.

Our drivebase has been done for a while but as a recap we’re using MK4n modules with Krakens.

Drivebase Incomplete 1920×1536 521 KB

Drivebase Incomplete 1920×1536 521 KB

Drivebase Incomplete 1920×1536 521 KB

## #Superstructure and Bellypan

We finished cutting out most of the parts for our superstructure and bellypan, though after more discussion we decided to switch from 1/8 in aluminum to 1/4in Lexan. The rotation of the superstructure is powered by 2 Kraken X60’s running into a 25:1 MaxPlanetary gearbox, which is then connected to a 48:32 gearing, and thats connected to a 44:9 #35 chain drive. This should give more than enough pivot power. To mate this with the drivetrain we basically just slide the bellypan and superstructure in from the top and then secure it with 12 bolts.

Superstructure Unmounted 1920×1080 288 KB

Superstructure Unmounted 1920×1080 288 KB

Superstructure Unmounted 1920×1080 288 KB

posts.name: Rishabh
posts.cooked:
We made some major progress today with mounting everything and got our superstructure connected to the bellypan. We then mounted that subassembly to the frame. Wiring still has to be finished, but the goal is to have the robot drivebase running on the field by end of tomorrow.

Photo featuring some of our ecstatic build members!

20250205_212902 1920×3404 688 KB

20250205_212902 1920×3404 688 KB

20250205_212902 1920×3404 688 KB

We also finished the elevator’s lift gearbox and attached it to the base stage. The only part we are waiting for now is the bearing blocks from SDS , which are supposed to arrive on Monday.

20250205_210327 1920×3413 681 KB 20250205_212918 1920×3413 653 KB

20250205_210327 1920×3413 681 KB

20250205_210327 1920×3413 681 KB

20250205_212918 1920×3413 653 KB

20250205_212918 1920×3413 653 KB

posts.name: Rishabh
posts.cooked:
We made a lot of progress, especially today (Saturday) and are currently looking at having our robot done by Wednesday of this week.

image 500×605 81.4 KB

image 500×605 81.4 KB

image 500×605 81.4 KB

Our programming team was finally able to get their hands on the drivetrain and get it running. This is our first time ever making a drivetrain with no CAN errors on the first try.

After about 2 weeks of waiting we got our SDS Bearing Blocks in and were able to fully assemble the elevator. All that’s left now is rigging the elevator with string and it should be fully functional.

20250208_203746 1920×3404 646 KB (It looks a bit funky because of the 0.5x lens)

20250208_203746 1920×3404 646 KB

20250208_203746 1920×3404 646 KB

So far we are weighing in at 89.0 lbs. with all motors and parts minus end effector and elevator wiring. Our CAD estimated weight is 105 lbs. so we should have plenty of wiggle room.

20250208_203703 1920×3404 475 KB

20250208_203703 1920×3404 475 KB

20250208_203703 1920×3404 475 KB

posts.name: Rishabh
posts.cooked:
Another week of mostly build progress with the goal being to have the robot handed off to programming by Friday

We mounted our elevator to our superstructure and tested out the tilt. We found that the tilt worked fine, however the shaft tilt MaxSpline was interfering with the lift pulleys and so we decided to cut the MaxSpline into two separate reinforced segements, which allowed for the space in the back to clear up and let the elevator lift up.

We started to create our bumpers and were using a new attachment method this year as suggested by Howdybots at San Antonio last year. We are use Southco latches in combination with 1/4in bolts and custom 3d printed latch mounts.

posts.name: AllenGregoryIV
posts.cooked:
endorphin:

We are use Southco latches in combination with 1/4in bolts and custom 3d printed latch mounts.

Do you have close up pictures and links to the latches?

posts.name: Rishabh
posts.cooked:
We’re using the Southco R4-05-20-405-10 Rotary Latches on custom 3D printed blocks. If you need the STEP/STL file for it just let me know. 20250213_210909 1920×3413 430 KB

20250213_210909 1920×3413 430 KB

20250213_210909 1920×3413 430 KB

Here’s a close up clip of the latching mechanism

posts.name: Xavier E.
posts.cooked: We just got our order in today. Would love if you could share the STL file with us. That looks really solid.

posts.name: Rishabh
posts.cooked:
Heres the link to both the original and mirrored versions:

https://pdm.getbild.com/public/files/be3447f7-619a-4065-b18e-0e1ec00abb34

posts.name: Rishabh
posts.cooked:
Small update today: We were able rig our elevator completely today and installed our hardstops for the elevator. We also finished our blue bumpers (without numbers) and tested scoring L4 Coral. Along with this we also weighed our robot with it coming in at 92.4 Lbs without elevator wiring.

20250213_211430 1920×3413 255 KB 20250213_211427 1920×3413 628 KB

20250213_211430 1920×3413 255 KB 20250213_211427 1920×3413 628 KB

20250213_211430 1920×3413 255 KB

20250213_211430 1920×3413 255 KB

20250213_211427 1920×3413 628 KB

20250213_211427 1920×3413 628 KB

posts.name: Rishabh
posts.cooked:
We finished assembling most of our robot on Saturday and finished electrical today, which let programming take over and start testing out the code that they have already developed. After seeing how our elevator would slowly start to droop if the motors were braked, we changed the pivot ratio from a 25:1 to a 45:1 which solved the issue.

20250217_204758 1920×3413 743 KB

20250217_204758 1920×3413 743 KB

20250217_204758 1920×3413 743 KB

posts.name: Rishabh
posts.cooked:
One of the main big things that has changed from last week is that we decided to simplify our end effector from both programming and weight reasons. We decided to use prong style end effector which we tested and found works really well.

Our programmers finally got their hands on our elevator and were able to get it to run after much trial and error.

All of the parts for our climb system finally came in and we are planning on mounting it to the rear of the robot tomorrow

20250225_212400 1920×3413 441 KB

20250225_212400 1920×3413 441 KB

20250225_212400 1920×3413 441 KB

posts.name: Rishabh
posts.cooked:
20250315_160602 1920×1440 383 KB

20250315_160602 1920×1440 383 KB

20250315_160602 1920×1440 383 KB

Oh boy has it been a stressful few weeks

We ended up taking the robot home after build hours to work on it because with the time that we had at the RSC we weren’t going to be able to finish by San Antonio. While there we tested our setpoints for scoring along with our vision setup.

image 1280×1707 251 KB

image 1280×1707 251 KB

image 1280×1707 251 KB

We also got a chance to install our LED’s which were wired to a REV Blinkin which let us create LED patterns with minimal coding. 20250310_232903 1920×3413 290 KB

20250310_232903 1920×3413 290 KB

20250310_232903 1920×3413 290 KB

We also lowered the climb mounting on our robot in order to allow us to climb more, though this led to more having to be done on the drivers side. We still plan on improving our climber, possibly taking inspiration from 2910’s design.

We spent this weekend competing at the First In Texas San Antonio District competition where we ended up 38th after quals due to a not so great match schedule and 3rd overall after losing to alliance 6 in the lower bracket final round by 3 points. We also won the Engineering Inspiration award at the competition.

20250315_175338 1920×3413 373 KB

20250315_175338 1920×3413 373 KB

20250315_175338 1920×3413 373 KB

This was a week where we found out how important our sponsors are to our success.

One of our sponsors, The LaQuinta Brookshire , let us use one of their meeting rooms in order to test the robot. 20250311_113702 1920×3413 763 KB

20250311_113702 1920×3413 763 KB

20250311_113702 1920×3413 763 KB

Another big thanks goes to our sponsor Aispex for helping power our robot cart and technology while on the go!

20250313_210150 1920×1083 415 KB

20250313_210150 1920×1083 415 KB

20250313_210150 1920×1083 415 KB
